# _Liberté, égalité, fraternité_

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Jump to navigation Jump to search

"Brotherhood of man" redirects here. For the musical group, see [Brotherhood
of Man](/wiki/Brotherhood_of_Man "Brotherhood of Man").

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/c/c3/Flag_of_France.svg/200px-
Flag_of_France.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Flag_of_France.svg)

[](/wiki/File:Flag_of_France.svg "Enlarge")

[Flag of France](/wiki/Flag_of_France "Flag of France") which represents
_Liberté, égalité, fraternité_

_**Liberté, égalité, fraternité**_ (pronounced [[libɛʁte eɡalite
fʁatɛʁnite]](/wiki/Help:IPA/French "Help:IPA/French")),
[French](/wiki/French_language "French language") for "[liberty](/wiki/Liberty
"Liberty"), [equality](/wiki/Social_equality "Social equality"),
[fraternity](/wiki/Fraternity_\(philosophy\) "Fraternity \(philosophy\)")",[1]
is the [national motto](/wiki/National_motto "National motto") of
[France](/wiki/France "France") and the [Republic of
Haiti](/wiki/Republic_of_Haiti "Republic of Haiti"), and is an example of a
[tripartite motto](/wiki/Tripartite_motto "Tripartite motto"). Although it
finds its origins in the [French Revolution](/wiki/French_Revolution "French
Revolution"), it was then only one motto among others and was not
institutionalized until the [Third Republic](/wiki/French_Third_Republic
"French Third Republic") at the end of the 19th century.[2] Debates concerning
the compatibility and order of the three terms began at the same time as the
Revolution. It is also the motto of the [Grand Orient de
France](/wiki/Grand_Orient_de_France "Grand Orient de France") and the [Grande
Loge de France](/wiki/Grande_Loge_de_France "Grande Loge de France").

    * 2.1 1848 Revolution

  * 3 20th century

## Origins during the French
Revolution[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Libert%C3%A9,_%C3%A9galit%C3%A9,_fraternit%C3%A9&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Origins during the French Revolution")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b6/LibertyEqualityorDeath.jpg/220px-
LibertyEqualityorDeath.jpg)](/wiki/File:LibertyEqualityorDeath.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:LibertyEqualityorDeath.jpg "Enlarge")

Text displayed on a placard announcing the sale of _[biens
nationaux](/wiki/Biens_nationaux "Biens nationaux")_ (1793). Soon after the
Revolution, the motto was sometimes written as "Liberty, Equality, Fraternity,
or Death". The "death" part was later dropped for being too strongly
associated with the [Reign of Terror](/wiki/Reign_of_Terror "Reign of
Terror").

The first to express this motto was [Maximilien
Robespierre](/wiki/Maximilien_Robespierre "Maximilien Robespierre") in his
speech _" On the organization of the National Guard"_
([French](/wiki/French_language "French language"): _Discours sur l
'organisation des gardes nationales_) on 5 December 1790, article XVI, and
disseminated widely throughout France by the popular Societies.

> **Discours sur l 'organisation des gardes nationales**  
> Article XVI.  
> On their uniforms engraved these words: FRENCH PEOPLE, & below: LIBERTY,
> EQUALITY, FRATERNITY. The same words are inscribed on flags which bear the
> three colors of the nation.  
> ([French](/wiki/French_language "French language"): _XVI. Elles porteront
> sur leur poitrine ces mots gravés : LE PEUPLE FRANÇAIS, & au-dessous :
> LIBERTÉ, ÉGALITÉ, FRATERNITÉ. Les mêmes mots seront inscrits sur leurs
> drapeaux, qui porteront les trois couleurs de la nation._)
>
> — Maximilien Robespierre, 1790[1][3][4]

Credit for the motto has been given also to [Antoine-François
Momoro](/wiki/Antoine-Fran%C3%A7ois_Momoro "Antoine-François Momoro")
(1756–94), a Parisian printer and [Hébertist](/wiki/H%C3%A9bertists
"Hébertists") organizer,[5][6][7] though in different context of foreign
invasion and [Federalist revolts](/wiki/Federalist_revolts "Federalist
revolts") in 1793, it was modified to "Unity, indivisibility of the Republic;
liberty, equality, brotherhood or death" ([French](/wiki/French_language
"French language"): _Unité, Indivisibilité de la République; Liberté, Egalité,
Fraternité ou la mort_) and suggested by a resolution of the [Paris
Commune](/wiki/Paris_Commune_\(French_Revolution\) "Paris Commune \(French
Revolution\)") (member of which Momoro was elected by his [section du Théâtre-
Français](/wiki/Section_du_Th%C3%A9%C3%A2tre-Fran%C3%A7ais "Section du
Théâtre-Français")) on 29 June 1793 to be inscribed on Parisian house-fronts
and imitated by the inhabitants of other cities. In 1839, the philosopher
[Pierre Leroux](/wiki/Pierre_Leroux "Pierre Leroux") claimed it had been an
anonymous and popular creation.[2][_[page
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citing_sources "Wikipedia:Citing sources")_] The
historian Mona Ozouf underlines that, although _Liberté_ and _Égalité_ were
associated as a motto during the 18th century, _Fraternité_ wasn't always
included in it, and other terms, such as _Amitié_ (Friendship), _Charité_
(Charity) or _Union_ were often added in its place.[2]

The emphasis on _Fraternité_ during the French Revolution led [Olympe de
Gouges](/wiki/Olympe_de_Gouges "Olympe de Gouges"), a female journalist, to
write the [Declaration of the Rights of Woman and the Female
Citizen](/wiki/Declaration_of_the_Rights_of_Woman_and_the_Female_Citizen
"Declaration of the Rights of Woman and the Female Citizen")[8][_[page
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citing_sources "Wikipedia:Citing sources")_] as a
response. The tripartite motto was neither a creative collection, nor really
institutionalized by the French Revolution.[2] As soon as 1789, other terms
were used, such as "_la Nation, la Loi, le Roi_ " (The Nation, The Law, The
King), or "_Union, Force, Vertu_ " (Union, Strength, Virtue), a slogan used
beforehand by [masonic lodges](/wiki/Freemasonry "Freemasonry"), or "_Force,
Égalité, Justice_ " (Strength, Equality, Justice), "_Liberté, Sûreté,
Propriété_ " (Liberty, Security, Property), etc.[2]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/90/Enseigne_Alsacienne_revolutionnaire.jpg/170px-
Enseigne_Alsacienne_revolutionnaire.jpg)](/wiki/File:Enseigne_Alsacienne_revolutionnaire.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Enseigne_Alsacienne_revolutionnaire.jpg "Enlarge")

Alsatian sign, 1792:  
_Freiheit Gleichheit Brüderlichk. od. Tod_ (Liberty Equality Fraternity or
Death)  
_Tod den Tyranen_ (Death to Tyrants)  
_Heil den Völkern_ (Long live the Peoples)

In other words, _liberté, égalité, fraternité_ was only one slogan among many
others.[2] During the [Jacobin](/wiki/Jacobin_Club "Jacobin Club")
revolutionary period itself, various mottos were used, such as _liberté,
unité, égalité_ (liberty, unity, equality); _liberté, égalité, justice_
(liberty, equality, justice); _liberté, raison, égalité_ (liberty, reason,
equality), etc.[2] The only solid association was that of _liberté_ and
_égalité_ , _fraternité_ being ignored by the _[Cahiers de
doléances](/wiki/Cahiers_de_dol%C3%A9ances "Cahiers de doléances")_ as well as
by the 1789 [Declaration of the Rights of Man and of the
Citizen](/wiki/Declaration_of_the_Rights_of_Man_and_of_the_Citizen
"Declaration of the Rights of Man and of the Citizen"). It was only alluded to
in the 1791 [Constitution](/wiki/French_Constitution "French Constitution"),
as well as in [Robespierre](/wiki/Robespierre "Robespierre")'s draft
Declaration of 1793, placed under the invocation of (in that order) _égalité,
liberté, sûreté_ and _propriété_ (equality, liberty, safety, property — though
it was used not as a motto, but as articles of declaration), as the
possibility of a universal extension of the Declaration of Rights: "Men of all
countries are brothers, he who oppresses one nation declares himself the enemy
of all."[2][a] Finally, it did not figure in the August 1793 Declaration.[2]

The [Declaration of the Rights of Man and of the
Citizen](/wiki/Declaration_of_the_Rights_of_Man_and_of_the_Citizen
"Declaration of the Rights of Man and of the Citizen") of 1789 defined liberty
in Article 4 as follows:

> Liberty consists of being able to do anything that does not harm others:
> thus, the exercise of the natural rights of every man or woman has no bounds
> other than those that guarantee other members of society the enjoyment of
> these same rights.

Equality, on the other hand, was defined by the 1789 Declaration in terms of
judicial equality and merit-based entry to government (art. 6):

> [The law] "must be the same for all, whether it protects or punishes. All
> citizens, being equal in its eyes, shall be equally eligible to all high
> offices, public positions and employments, according to their ability, and
> without other distinction than that of their virtues and talents."

_Liberté, égalité, fraternité_ actually finds its origins in a May 1791
proposition by the _[Club des Cordeliers](/wiki/Cordeliers "Cordeliers")_ ,
following a speech on the Army by the [marquis de
Guichardin](/w/index.php?title=Marquis_de_Guichardin&action=edit&redlink=1
"Marquis de Guichardin \(page does not exist\)").[2] A British marine held
prisoner on the French ship _Le Marat_ in 1794 wrote home in letters published
in 1796:[9]

> The republican spirit is inculcated not in songs only, for in every part of
> the ship I find emblems purposely displayed to awaken it. All the orders
> relating to the discipline of the crew are hung up, and prefaced by the
> words _Liberté, Égalité, Fraternité, ou la Mort_ , written in capital
> letters.

The compatibility of _liberté_ and _égalité_ was not doubted in the first days
of the Revolution, and the problem of the antecedence of one term on the other
not lifted.[2] Thus, the [Abbé Sieyès](/wiki/Abb%C3%A9_Siey%C3%A8s "Abbé
Sieyès") considered that only liberty ensured equality, unless the latter was
to be the equality of all dominated by a [despot](/wiki/Despotism
"Despotism"); while liberty followed equality ensured by the rule of law.[2]
The abstract generality of law (theorized by [Jean-Jacques
Rousseau](/wiki/Jean-Jacques_Rousseau "Jean-Jacques Rousseau") in _[The Social
Contract](/wiki/The_Social_Contract "The Social Contract")_) thus ensured the
identification of liberty to equality, liberty being negatively defined as an
independence from arbitrary rule, and equality considered abstractly in its
judicial form.[2]

This identification of liberty and equality became problematic during the
Jacobin period, when equality was redefined (for instance by [François-Noël
Babeuf](/wiki/Fran%C3%A7ois-No%C3%ABl_Babeuf "François-Noël Babeuf")) as
[equality of results](/wiki/Equality_of_outcome "Equality of outcome"), and
not only judicial equality of rights.[2] Thus, [Marc Antoine
Baudot](/wiki/Marc_Antoine_Baudot "Marc Antoine Baudot") considered that
French temperament inclined rather to equality than liberty, a theme which
would be re-used by [Pierre Louis Roederer](/wiki/Pierre_Louis_Roederer
"Pierre Louis Roederer") and [Alexis de
Tocqueville](/wiki/Alexis_de_Tocqueville "Alexis de Tocqueville"), while
[Jacques Necker](/wiki/Jacques_Necker "Jacques Necker") considered that an
equal society could only be found on coercion.[2]

The third term, _fraternité_ , was the most problematic to insert in the
triad, as it belonged to another sphere, that of moral obligations rather than
rights, links rather than statutes, harmony rather than
[contract](/wiki/Freedom_of_contract "Freedom of contract"), and community
rather than individuality.[2] Various interpretations of _fraternité_ existed.
The first one, according to Mona Ozouf, was one of "_fraternité de rébellion_
" (Fraternity of Rebellion),[2] that is the union of the deputies in the _[Jeu
de Paume Oath](/wiki/Tennis_Court_Oath "Tennis Court Oath")_ of June 1789,
refusing the dissolution ordered by the King [Louis XVI](/wiki/Louis_XVI
"Louis XVI"): "We swear never to separate ourselves from the [National
Assembly](/wiki/National_Assembly_\(French_Revolution\) "National Assembly
\(French Revolution\)"), and to reassemble wherever circumstances require,
until the constitution of the realm is drawn up and fixed upon solid
foundations." Fraternity was thus issued from Liberty and oriented by a common
cause.[2]

Another form of _fraternité_ was that of the patriotic Church, which
identified social link with religious link and based fraternity on Christian
brotherhood.[2] In this second sense, _fraternité_ preceded both _liberté_ and
_égalité_ , instead of following them as in the first sense.[2][_[page
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citing_sources "Wikipedia:Citing sources")_] Thus, two
senses of Fraternity: "one, that followed liberty and equality, was the object
of a free pact; the other preceded liberty and equality as the mark on its
work of the divine craftsman."[2]

Another hesitation concerning the compatibility of the three terms arose from
the opposition between liberty and equality as
[individualistic](/wiki/Individualism "Individualism") values, and fraternity
as the realization of a happy community, devoided of any conflicts and opposed
to any form of [egotism](/wiki/Egotism "Egotism").[2] This fusional
interpretation of Fraternity opposed it to the project of [individual
autonomy](/wiki/Self-ownership "Self-ownership") and manifested the precedence
of Fraternity on individual will.[2]

In this sense, it was sometimes associated with death, as in _Fraternité, ou
la Mort!_ (Fraternity or Death!), excluding liberty and even equality, by
establishing a strong dichotomy between those who were brothers and those who
were not (in the sense of "[you are with me or against
me](/wiki/You%27re_either_with_us,_or_against_us "You're either with us, or
against us")", brother or foe).[2][_[page
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citing_sources "Wikipedia:Citing sources")_] [Louis de
Saint-Just](/wiki/Louis_de_Saint-Just "Louis de Saint-Just") thus stigmatized
[Anarchasis Cloots](/wiki/Anarchasis_Cloots "Anarchasis Cloots")'
[cosmopolitanism](/wiki/Cosmopolitanism "Cosmopolitanism"), declaring "Cloots
liked the universe, except France."[2]

With [Thermidor](/wiki/Thermidorian_Reaction "Thermidorian Reaction") and the
execution of Robespierre, _fraternité_ disappeared from the slogan, reduced to
the two terms of liberty and equality, re-defined again as simple judicial
equality and not as the equality upheld by the sentiment of fraternity.[2] The
[First Consul](/wiki/First_Consul "First Consul") ([Napoleon
Bonaparte](/wiki/Napoleon_Bonaparte "Napoleon Bonaparte")) then established
the motto _liberté, ordre public_ (liberty, public order).

## 19th
century[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Libert%C3%A9,_%C3%A9galit%C3%A9,_fraternit%C3%A9&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: 19th century")]

Following Napoleon's rule, the triptych dissolved itself, as none believed
possible to conciliate individual liberty and equality of rights with
[equality of results](/wiki/Equality_of_outcome "Equality of outcome") and
fraternity.[2] The idea of [individual sovereignty](/wiki/Self-ownership
"Self-ownership") and of [natural rights](/wiki/Natural_rights "Natural
rights") possessed by man before being united in the collectivity contradicted
the possibility of establishing a transparent and fraternal community.[2]
[Liberals](/wiki/Liberalism "Liberalism") accepted liberty and equality,
defining the latter as equality of rights and ignoring fraternity.[2]

[Early Socialists](/wiki/Utopian_Socialism "Utopian Socialism") rejected an
independent conception of liberty, opposed to the social, and also despised
equality, as they considered, as [Fourier](/wiki/Charles_Fourier "Charles
Fourier"), that one had only to orchestrate individual discordances, to
harmonize them, or they believed, as [Saint-
Simon](/wiki/Claude_Henri_de_Rouvroy,_comte_de_Saint-Simon "Claude Henri de
Rouvroy, comte de Saint-Simon"), that equality contradicted
[equity](/wiki/Equity_\(economics\) "Equity \(economics\)") by a brutal
levelling of individualities.[2] Utopian Socialism thus only cared about
Fraternity, which was, in [Cabet](/wiki/Etienne_Cabet "Etienne Cabet")'s
[Icarie](/wiki/Icarians "Icarians") the sole commandment.[2]

This opposition between liberals and socialists was mirrored in rival
historical interpretations of the Revolution, liberals admiring 1789, and
Socialists 1793.[2] The [July Revolution](/wiki/July_Revolution "July
Revolution") of 1830, establishing a constitutional monarchy headed by [Louis-
Philippe](/wiki/Louis-Philippe_of_France "Louis-Philippe of France"),
substituted _ordre et liberté_ (order and liberty) to the Napoleonic motto
_Liberté, Ordre public_.[2] Despite this apparent disappearance of the
triptych, the latter was still being thought in some underground circles, in
Republican [secret societies](/wiki/Secret_societies "Secret societies"),
masonic lodges such as the "Indivisible Trinity," far-left booklets or during
the [Canuts Revolt](/wiki/Canuts_Revolt "Canuts Revolt") in Lyon.[2] In 1834,
the lawyer of the [Society of the Rights of
Man](/wiki/Society_of_the_Rights_of_Man "Society of the Rights of Man")
(Société des droits de l'homme), [Dupont](/wiki/Jacques-
Charles_Dupont_de_l%27Eure "Jacques-Charles Dupont de l'Eure"), a liberal
sitting in the far-left during the [July Monarchy](/wiki/July_Monarchy "July
Monarchy"), associated the three terms together in the _[Revue
Républicaine](/w/index.php?title=Revue_R%C3%A9publicaine&action=edit&redlink=1
"Revue Républicaine \(page does not exist\)")_ which he edited:

> Any man aspires to liberty, to equality, but he can not achieve it without
> the assistance of other men, without fraternity[2][b]

The triptych resurfaced during the 1847 _[Campagne des
Banquets](/wiki/Campagne_des_Banquets "Campagne des Banquets")_ , upheld for
example in [Lille](/wiki/Lille "Lille") by [Ledru-Rollin](/wiki/Ledru-Rollin
"Ledru-Rollin").[2]

Two interpretations had attempted to conciliate the three terms, beyond the
antagonism between liberals and socialists. One was upheld by Catholic
traditionalists, such as [Chateaubriand](/wiki/Chateaubriand "Chateaubriand")
or [Ballanche](/wiki/Ballanche "Ballanche"), the other by socialist and
republicans such as [Pierre Leroux](/wiki/Pierre_Leroux "Pierre Leroux").[2]
Chateaubriand thus gave a Christian interpretation of the revolutionary motto,
stating in the 1841 conclusion to his _Mémoires d 'outre-tombe_:

> Far from being at its term, the religion of the Liberator is now only just
> entering its third phase, the political period, liberty, equality,
> fraternity[2][c]

Neither Chateaubriand nor Ballanche considered the three terms to be
antagonistic. Rather, they took them for being the achievement of
Christianity. On the other hand, Pierre Leroux did not disguise the
difficulties of associating the three terms, but superated it by considering
liberty as the aim, equality as the principle and fraternity as the means.[2]
Leroux thus ordered the motto as Liberty, Fraternity, Equality,[2] an order
also supported by [Christian socialists](/wiki/Christian_socialism "Christian
socialism"), such as [Buchez](/wiki/Buchez "Buchez").[2]

Against this new order of the triptych, [Michelet](/wiki/Jules_Michelet "Jules
Michelet") supported the traditional order, maintaining the primordial
importance of an original individualistic right.[2] Michelet attempted to
conciliate a rational communication with a fraternal communication, "right
beyond right",[2][_[page needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citing_sources
"Wikipedia:Citing sources")_] and thus the rival traditions of Socialism and
Liberalism.[2] The [Republican](/wiki/Republicanism "Republicanism") tradition
would strongly inspire itself from Michelet's synchretism.[2]

### 1848
Revolution[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Libert%C3%A9,_%C3%A9galit%C3%A9,_fraternit%C3%A9&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: 1848 Revolution")]

_Liberté, égalité, fraternité_ on French coins

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2d/France_5_francs_1849.jpg/200px-
France_5_francs_1849.jpg)](/wiki/File:France_5_francs_1849.jpg)

5-franc piece, 1849

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/53/France_20_francs_1851.jpg/200px-
France_20_francs_1851.jpg)](/wiki/File:France_20_francs_1851.jpg)

20-franc piece, 1851

With the [1848 February Revolution](/wiki/1848_February_Revolution "1848
February Revolution"), the motto was officially adopted,[10] mainly under the
pressure of the people who had attempted to impose the [red
flag](/wiki/Red_flag_\(politics\) "Red flag \(politics\)") over the [tricolor
flag](/wiki/Flag_of_France "Flag of France") (the 1791 red flag was, however,
the symbol of martial law and of order, not of insurrection).[2]
[Lamartine](/wiki/Lamartine "Lamartine") opposed popular aspirations, and in
exchange of the maintaining of the tricolor flag, conceded the Republican
motto of _Liberté, Égalité, Fraternité_ , written on the flag, on which a red
rosette was also to be added.[2]

Fraternity was then considered to resume and to contain both Liberty and
Equality, being a form of civil religion (which, far from opposing itself to
Christianity, was associated with it in 1848[2][_[page
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citing_sources "Wikipedia:Citing sources")_])
establishing social link (as called for by Rousseau in the conclusion of the
_Social Contract_).[2]

However, Fraternity was not devoid of its previous sense of opposition between
brothers and foes, images of blood haunting revolutionary Christian
publications, taking in [Lamennais](/wiki/Lamennais "Lamennais")' themes.[2]
Thus, the newspaper _[Le Christ
républicain](/w/index.php?title=Le_Christ_r%C3%A9publicain&action=edit&redlink=1
"Le Christ républicain \(page does not exist\)")_ (The Republican Christ)
developed the idea of the Christ bringing forth peace to the poor and war to
the rich.[2][11]

As soon as 6 January 1852, the future [Napoleon
III](/wiki/Napoleon_III_of_France "Napoleon III of France"), first President
of the Republic, ordered all [prefects](/wiki/Prefects_of_France "Prefects of
France") to erase the triptych from all official documents and buildings,
conflated with insurrection and disorder.[2] [Auguste
Comte](/wiki/Auguste_Comte "Auguste Comte") applauded Napoleon, claiming
equality to be the "symbol of metaphysical anarchism", and preferring to it
his diptych "_ordre et progrès_ " ("order and progress", which would then
become the motto of Brazil, [Ordem e Progresso](/wiki/Ordem_e_Progresso "Ordem
e Progresso")).[12] On the other hand, [Proudhon](/wiki/Proudhon "Proudhon")
criticized fraternity as an empty word, which he associated with idealistic
dreams of [Romanticism](/wiki/Romanticism "Romanticism").[2] He preferred to
it the sole term of liberty.

### Paris Commune and Third
Republic[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Libert%C3%A9,_%C3%A9galit%C3%A9,_fraternit%C3%A9&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: Paris Commune and Third Republic")]

Pache, mayor of the [Paris Commune](/wiki/Paris_Commune "Paris Commune"),
painted the formula "Liberté, Égalité, Fraternité, ou la mort" on the walls of
the commune. It was only under the [Third
Republic](/wiki/French_Third_Republic "French Third Republic") that the motto
was made official. It was then not dissociated with insurrection and
revolutionary ardours, [Opportunist Republicans](/wiki/Opportunist_Republicans
"Opportunist Republicans") such as [Jules Ferry](/wiki/Jules_Ferry "Jules
Ferry") or [Gambetta](/wiki/L%C3%A9on_Gambetta "Léon Gambetta") adapting it to
the new political conditions.[2][_[page needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citing_sources
"Wikipedia:Citing sources")_] [Larousse](/wiki/Pierre_Larousse "Pierre
Larousse")'s _Dictionnaire universel_ deprived fraternity of its "evangelistic
halo" (Mona Ozouf), conflating it with solidarity and the [welfare
role](/wiki/Welfare_state "Welfare state") of the state.[2]

Some still opposed the Republican motto, such as the nationalist [Charles
Maurras](/wiki/Charles_Maurras "Charles Maurras") in his _Dictionnaire
politique et critique_ , who claimed liberty to be an empty dream, equality an
insanity, and only kept fraternity.[2] [Charles
Péguy](/wiki/Charles_P%C3%A9guy "Charles Péguy"), renewing with Lamennais'
thought, kept fraternity and liberty, excluding equality, seen as an abstract
repartition between individuals reduced to homogeneity,[2] opposing
"fraternity" as a sentiment put in motion by "misery", while equality only
interested itself, according to him, to the mathematical solution of the
problem of "poverty."[2]

Péguy identified Christian charity and socialist solidarity in this conception
of fraternity.[2] On the other hand, [Georges Vacher de
Lapouge](/wiki/Georges_Vacher_de_Lapouge "Georges Vacher de Lapouge"), the
most important French author of [pseudo-scientific
racism](/wiki/Scientific_racism "Scientific racism") and supporter of
[eugenism](/wiki/Eugenism "Eugenism"), completely rejected the Republican
triptych, adopting another motto, "_déterminisme, inégalité, sélection_ "
(determinism, inequality, selection). But, according to Ozouf, the sole use of
a triptych was the sign of the influence of the Republican motto, despite it
being corrupted in its opposite.[2]

## 20th
century[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Libert%C3%A9,_%C3%A9galit%C3%A9,_fraternit%C3%A9&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: 20th century")]

During the [German occupation of France in World War
II](/wiki/German_occupation_of_France_in_World_War_II "German occupation of
France in World War II"), this motto was replaced by the reactionary phrase
"_[travail, famille, patrie](/wiki/Travail,_famille,_patrie "Travail, famille,
patrie")_ " (work, family, fatherland)[13] by [Marshal
Pétain](/wiki/Philippe_P%C3%A9tain "Philippe Pétain"), who became the leader
of the new [Vichy](/wiki/Vichy_France "Vichy France") French government in
1940. Pétain had taken this motto from the [colonel de la
Rocque](/wiki/Colonel_de_la_Rocque "Colonel de la Rocque")'s _[Parti social
français](/wiki/Parti_social_fran%C3%A7ais "Parti social français")_ (PSF),
although the latter considered it more appropriate for a movement than for a
regime.[2]

Following the Liberation, the [Provisional Government of the French
Republic](/wiki/Provisional_Government_of_the_French_Republic "Provisional
Government of the French Republic") (GPRF) re-established the Republican motto
_Liberté, égalité, fraternité_ , which is incorporated into both the 1946 and
the 1958 French constitutions.[1]

## Other
nations[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Libert%C3%A9,_%C3%A9galit%C3%A9,_fraternit%C3%A9&action=edit&section=6
"Edit section: Other nations")]

Many other nations have adopted the French slogan of "liberty, equality, and
fraternity" as an ideal. These words appear in the
[preamble](/wiki/Preamble_to_the_Constitution_of_India "Preamble to the
Constitution of India") to the [Constitution of
India](/wiki/Constitution_of_India "Constitution of India"), enforced in 1950.
Since its founding, "Liberty, Equality and Brotherhood" has been the lemma of
the Social Democratic Party of Denmark. In the [United
Kingdom](/wiki/United_Kingdom "United Kingdom") the political party the
[Liberal Democrats](/wiki/Liberal_Democrats_\(UK\) "Liberal Democrats \(UK\)")
refer to "the fundamental values of liberty, equality and community" in the
preamble of the party's Federal Constitution, and this is printed on party
membership cards.[14]

The Philippine national flag has a rectangular design that consists of a white
equilateral triangle, symbolizing liberty, equality, and fraternity; a
horizontal blue stripe for peace, truth, and justice; and a horizontal red
stripe for patriotism and valor . In the center of the white triangle is an
eight- rayed golden sun symbolizing unity, freedom, people's democracy, and
sovereignty.

The idea of the slogan "Liberty, Equality, Fraternity" has also given an
influence as [natural law](/wiki/Natural_law "Natural law") to the First
Article of the [Universal Declaration of Human
Rights](/wiki/Universal_Declaration_of_Human_Rights "Universal Declaration of
Human Rights"):

> All human beings are born free and equal in dignity and rights. They are
> endowed with reason and conscience and should act towards one another in a
> spirit of brotherhood.[15]

##
Culture[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Libert%C3%A9,_%C3%A9galit%C3%A9,_fraternit%C3%A9&action=edit&section=7
"Edit section: Culture")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/13/Liberte-egalite-
fraternite-tympanum-church-saint-pancrace-aups-var.jpg/300px-Liberte-egalite-
fraternite-tympanum-church-saint-pancrace-aups-var.jpg)](/wiki/File:Liberte-
egalite-fraternite-tympanum-church-saint-pancrace-aups-var.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Liberte-egalite-fraternite-tympanum-church-saint-pancrace-aups-
var.jpg "Enlarge")

[Tympanum](/wiki/Tympanum_\(architecture\) "Tympanum \(architecture\)") of a
state-owned [church](/wiki/Church_\(building\) "Church \(building\)")

At one point the motto was used to mark churches which were controlled by the
state, rather than the Catholic Church.

Some former colonies of the French Republic (such as [Haiti](/wiki/Haiti
"Haiti"), [Chad](/wiki/Chad "Chad"), [Niger](/wiki/Niger "Niger"), and
[Gabon](/wiki/Gabon "Gabon")) have adopted similar three-word mottos.

The terms are also referred to in the film trilogy [Three
Colors](/wiki/Three_Colors "Three Colors") by [Krzysztof
Kieślowski](/wiki/Krzysztof_Kie%C5%9Blowski "Krzysztof Kieślowski").
